dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, um, I just read something here that's like, wow. It says "almost 50 million people and more than a dozen cities are currently on lockdown." Like, fifty million people?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, um, I just read something here that's like, wow. It says almost fifty million people and more than a dozen cities are currently on lockdown. Like, fifty million people?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The spreading virus is already having an impact on consumer demand and tourism during the busy Lunar New Year period (almost 50 million people and more than a dozen cities are currently on lockdown), and U.S. companies with businesses in China are not exempt from the pain as some have already closed stores in the region.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, A, it's, uh, it's pretty intense. And that number, that situation, is really impacting everything right now. Especially the markets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, A, it's, uh, it's pretty intense. And that number, that situation, is really impacting everything right now. Especially the markets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, isn't this like, a huge week for company earnings? Like, Apple, Amazon, Facebook, they're all reporting, right? That should be good news.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, isn't this like, a huge week for company earnings? Like, Apple, Amazon, Facebook, they're all reporting, right? That should be good news.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its a huge week for earnings with Apple, Starbucks, Facebook, Amazon and others all reporting, even as investors grapple with the financial fallout from the deadly coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It should be, absolutely. It is a massive earnings week. But the coronavirus, um, is just completely overshadowing it. Investors are, like, really grappling with the fallout.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It should be, absolutely. It is a massive earnings week. But the coronavirus, um, is just completely overshadowing it. Investors are, like, really grappling with the fallout.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Typically during a week like this, all attention would be on earnings alone, but Chinas coronavirus is playing a huge role in the direction of stocks as the disease rapidly spreads with no vaccine in sight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, even with Amazon expecting, uh, what, $86 billion in sales? That's not enough to, like, calm things down?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, even with Amazon expecting, uh, what, eighty six dollars billion in sales? That's not enough to, like, calm things down?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amazon is expected to report $86 billion in sales and earnings per share of $4.05, and Tesla is expected to bring in $7.05 billion in revenue and earnings of $1.65 per share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not really, no. I mean, the market was already, uh, trading at what some analysts call "unsustainable valuations." The virus is just, you know, an added headwind.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not really, no. I mean, the market was already, uh, trading at what some analysts call unsustainable valuations. The virus is just, you know, an added headwind.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Making things even riskier for investors is a market thats trading at unsustainable valuations, according to Adam Crisafulli, founder of Vital Knowledge, who says that the coronavirus is acting as an added headwind at a time when stocks are becoming extraordinarily sensitive to even the smallest setbacks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, um, the S&P was down 1.6%, the Nasdaq 1.9%? That's a huge drop, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, um, the S&P was down one point six percent, the Nasdaq one point nine percent? That's a huge drop, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 was down 1.6%, the Nasdaq Composite index 1.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1.5%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's significant, yeah. We've seen, like, their worst losses in months. Crude oil prices also hit a three-month low.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's significant, yeah. We've seen, like, their worst losses in months. Crude oil prices also hit a three-month low.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All three major indexes are off to a rough start this week after recording their worst losses in months on Monday. ... Crude oil prices also hit a three-month low on Monday, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate falling to $53 per barrel.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But, uh, historically, haven't these kinds of outbreaks actually been, like, buying opportunities? I remember reading something about SARS.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, uh, historically, haven't these kinds of outbreaks actually been, like, buying opportunities? I remember reading something about S A R S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although historically these outbreaks have been buying opportunities, the bottom line is investors are taking a sell first and ask questions later approach right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: You're right. Historically, they often are. The S&P dropped 12% during SARS but ended the year up 19%. But right now, investors are, like, taking a 'sell first' approach.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You're right. Historically, they often are. The S&P dropped twelve percent during S A R S but ended the year up nineteen percent. But right now, investors are, like, taking a 'sell first' approach.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zaccarelli compares the coronavirus with the SARS outbreak: During the five-month period starting in mid-November 2002 until mid-March 2003, the S&P 500 dropped 12% but ended up actually finishing that year 19% higher than where it started, he notes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, the Chinese economy, like, will take a hit? And then, uh, it just bounces back later?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the Chinese economy, like, will take a hit? And then, uh, it just bounces back later?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese economyand possibly the world economywill take a hit in the short run, and lower prices are a rational response to the increasing spread of the coronavirus, predicts Chris Zaccarelli, chief investment officer for the Independent Advisor Alliance. However, over the medium term, this will likely prove to be a buying opportunity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's the hope, over the medium term, yeah. But the short-term impact on things like consumer demand, uh, and tourism is huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the hope, over the medium term, yeah. But the short-term impact on things like consumer demand, uh, and tourism is huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The spreading virus is already having an impact on consumer demand and tourism during the busy Lunar New Year period (almost 50 million people and more than a dozen cities are currently on lockdown)

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And wait, this article also says something about Tesla's stock being "artificially inflated" by social media? Like, what's that about?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And wait, this article also says something about Tesla's stock being artificially inflated by social media? Like, what's that about?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's, um, that's another layer of complexity for investors this week. Just adds to the general unease.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's, um, that's another layer of complexity for investors this week. Just adds to the general unease.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, the "worst is still yet to come" kind of thing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, the worst is still yet to come kind of thing?
